text: Can you hear me in the back?
You cannot.
All right. We'll have to...
Narrator: R. B. Woodward is a chemistry icon.

But for those who don’t know the man, his
iconography may be a little surprising.

For one, it includes cigarettes and daiquiris—it’s
more “Mad Men” than the mad scientist

tropes often foisted on the field: you know,
smoking beakers, fluorescent liquids, that
sort of thing.

But that’s not to say Woodward shied away
from reactions and reagents.

Some might even say he was destined for the
lab.

Here’s biochemist David Dolphin introducing
Woodward before a talk at Harvard in 1972
with the help of a horoscope he had prepared.
Dolphin: Clearly this man should be a scientist.

More than that, Pluto influences his personality
and he should be a chemist.
Now there's a challenge for you.

Narrator: It is tempting to think that stars
and planets guided Woodward’s endeavors.

Here’s an abbreviated list of his accomplishments
delivered by chemistry professor Howard Zimmerman
of the University of Wisconsin in 1979.

Zimmerman: Bob's known for his organic syntheses,
some of which, most of which, all of which

were really thought to be impossible at the
outset: quinine, cholesterol, cortisone, lanosterol,

lysergic acid, strychnine, reserpine, chlorophyll,
the tetracyclines, colchicine, cephalosporin,

the prostaglandins, vitamin B-12, and you
have it.

Narrator: Woodward was in Wisconsin speaking
about the total synthesis of the macrolide
antibiotic erythromycin.

His talk gives a sense of his deliberate nature
and, beyond that, what drew him to chemistry

and, in particular, stereochemistry, the challenge
of recreating nature’s atomic geometry.

Woodward: Many of those carbon atoms in the
naturally occurring macrolides are chiral sites.
that is, centers of asymmetry.

This situation presents to the synthetic chemist
a peculiar challenge.

That is, the challenge is that of devising
methods for creating asymmetric systems in

situations in which one does not have the
kind of control which is well known and well
worked out in rigid systems.

Narrator: Stereochemistry was also a major
challenge in Woodward’s synthesis of vitamin
B-12, as he describes in the 1972 lecture.

Woodward: Now the thing that strikes one immediately
about vitamin B-12 is the stereochemical situation.

This macrocyclic nucleus contains no less
than nine chiral centers.

The molecule then--the structure--presented
a challenge and an opportunity to the synthetic

chemist to test the principles that he knew
and, perhaps, to develop new ones.

Much of the interest in this problem devolves
from the stereochemical content,
its stereochemical content.

Narrator: These video clips are glazed in
a nostalgia that invites the thought that

maybe Woodward’s noble obsession, like smoking
in a lecture hall, is a hallmark of a bygone era.

It’s an alluring thought, but one that we
think is false.
His passion still permeates chemistry.

Now, there is absolutely something special
about seeing Woodward through the lens of
a 40-year-old camera.

But some of that is seeing reminders that
still hold up today, like that there is room
in chemistry for humility.

Woodward: Now, altogether, over a period of
11 years, Professor Eschenmoser and I had
99 associates in this work.

And they are, of course, the people who actually
accomplished the synthesis and it is to their
credit, very much so.

They were a very devoted and skillful group
of people.

I have described reactions very casually as
though they just could be carried out by pouring

things from one bottle to another but in almost
every case, almost every case, the reactions

I've described had to be carried out under
extremely carefully defined and prescribed
conditions with all sorts of special precautions.

I may say also that much of the work which
was done in exploring the ways to find the

routes which were ultimately discovered was
done at a very small scale, on the order of
50 micrograms or so.

When you're 75 steps away from home, you don't
want to use up much material in each experiment

and you may have to do hundreds of experiments
or even thousands.
And so you use very small quantities of material.

And when you want to exclude absolutely rigorously
oxygen or moisture from a reaction on the

50-microgram scale, that's a chemist that
can do that.

Narrator: These old videos are magical and
don't take our word for it.

You can watch them in their entirety on Thomas
Hoye’s website.

We owe a huge thanks to Hoye, who is a professor
of chemistry at the University of Minnesota.

He shared this footage with us and we also
need to thank Professor Addison Ault of Cornell
College in Iowa for making the footage available.

If you want to stay up to date with all things
chemistry, click on our red logo to subscribe

to our YouTube channel and hit that blue icon
to subscribe to our weekly newsletter.
Thanks for watching.
